wikipedia_page.main: Robert Williams (23 January 1811 – 7 June 1890) was a Conservative Party politician in the United Kingdom.

response: However, Graham's tenure in Pembroke was short-lived. In the 1841 general election, Sir John Owen chose to reclaim Pembroke; Graham felt honour-bound to comply and did not stand. Instead, Robert Williams, MP for Dorchester, stood down in favor of Graham, who was elected unopposed there. Sir Robert Peel became Prime Minister and appointed Graham Home Secretary in his cabinet.

| Robert Williams

Robert Williams (11 February 1767 – 10 March 1847) was an English banker and politician.John Burke, A genealogical and heraldic history of the commoners of Great Britain and Ireland (1836) at p. 618 He purchased the Bridehead estate near Dorchester, Dorset, around 1797.http://www.parksandgardens.ac.uk/component/option,com_parksandgardens/task,site/id,535/tab,history/Itemid,293/ It comprised the manor of Littlebredy, Bridehead being a name fabricated by Williams,http://www.burtonbradstock.org.uk/History/C%20J%20Baileys%20The%20Bride%20Valley/The%20Natural%20Setting.htm and in later years became the main family residence.
He married Frances Turner of Putney. His eldest son was Robert Williams (1811–1890).
#REDIRECT Robert Williams (1811–1890)
* Robert Williams, Conservative politician

On 24 May 1808, he married Harriet Williams, a daughter of banker and politician Robert Williams, Esq. of Bridehead in County Durham MP.  Her brother was Robert Williams, MP for Dorchester. Before her death on 7 July 1831, they were the parents of four children:
